title-group.article-title: Association Among County-Level Economic Factors, Clinician Supply, Metropolitan or Rural Location, and Neonatal Abstinence Syndrome
title-group.alt-title: Association of US County-Level Unemployment and Clinician Supply With Rates of NAS
Association of US County-Level Unemployment and Clinician Supply With Rates of NAS

author-notes.title: Article Information
author-notes.corresp: Corresponding Author: Stephen W. Patrick, MD, MPH, MS, Vanderbilt Center for Child Health Policy, 2525 West End Ave, Ste 1200, Nashville, TN 37203 (stephen.patrick@vanderbilt.edu).
author-notes.p: Author Contributions: Drs Patrick and Dick had full access to all of the data in the study and take responsibility for the integrity of the data and the accuracy of the data analysis.
Concept and design: Patrick, Faherty, Dick, Stein.
Acquisition, analysis, or interpretation of data: All authors.
Drafting of the manuscript: Patrick, Dick.
Critical revision of the manuscript for important intellectual content: All authors.
Administrative, technical, or material support: Patrick, Dick, Stein.
Conflict of Interest Disclosures: None reported.

Funding/Support: This research was supported by funding from the National Institute for Healthcare Management Foundation (awarded to Dr Patrick); award number K23DA038720 (awarded to Dr Patrick) and grants R01DA045729 (awarded to Dr Patrick), R21DA045212 (awarded to Dr Faherty), and P50DA046351 (awarded to Dr Stein) from the National Institute on Drug Abuse of the National Institutes of Health; and generous donor contributions to RAND Health Care.

Role of the Funder/Sponsor: The funders had no role in the design and conduct of the study; collection, management, analysis, and interpretation of the data; preparation, review, or approval of the manuscript; and decision to submit the manuscript for publication.
Disclaimer: The content is solely the responsibility of the authors and does not necessarily represent the official views of the National Institutes of Health or RAND Health Care.

Additional Contributions: We thank Augustine Faucher, PhD (PNC Financial Services Group), for his contribution in interpreting community unemployment characteristics. We also thank Kim Lovell, MPH, MBA (Vanderbilt University), and Hilary Peterson, BA (RAND), for their editorial assistance. No compensation was provided for their roles.

related-article.article-title: Structural Factors Shape the Effects of the Opioid Epidemic on Pregnant Women and Infants.

sec.title: Question
sec.p: What is the association among a county’s economy, clinician supply, and neonatal abstinence syndrome?

sec.title: Findings
sec.p: In this retrospective repeated cross-sectional study that included 580 US counties and 6 302 497 births, there was a significant association with county-level rates of neonatal abstinence syndrome and county 10-year unemployment rate (adjusted incidence rate ratio, 1.11) and designation as a mental health clinician shortage area (adjusted incidence rate ratio, 1.17).

sec.title: Meaning
sec.p: Long-term unemployment and shortage of mental health clinicians were associated with higher rates of neonatal abstinence syndrome on a county level.

sec.title: Importance
sec.p: Neonatal abstinence syndrome (NAS) has increased over the last 2 decades, but limited data exist on its association with economic conditions or clinician supply.

sec.title: Objective
sec.p: To determine the association among long-term unemployment, clinician supply (as assessed by primary care and mental health clinician shortage areas), and rates of NAS and evaluate how associations differ based on rurality.

sec.title: Design, Setting, and Participants
sec.p: Ecological time-series analysis of a retrospective, repeated cross-sectional study using outcome data from all 580 counties in Florida, Kentucky, Massachusetts, Michigan, New York, North Carolina, Tennessee, and Washington from 2009 to 2015 and economic data from 2000 to 2015. Negative binomial models were used with year and county-level fixed effects. Interactions were tested and stratified analyses were conducted by metropolitan counties, rural counties adjacent to metropolitan counties, and rural remote counties.

sec.title: Exposures
sec.p: County-level 10-year unemployment rate and mental health and primary care clinician supply obtained from the Health Resources and Services Administration Area Health Resources Files.

sec.title: Main Outcomes and Measure
sec.p: Rates of NAS, excluding iatrogenic withdrawal, obtained from state inpatient databases.

sec.title: Results
sec.p: The sample included observations from 580 counties over 7 years (1803 county-years from metropolitan counties, 1268 county-years from rural counties adjacent to metropolitan counties, and 927 county-years from rural remote counties). During the study period, there were 6 302 497 births and 47 224 diagnoses of NAS. The median rate of NAS was 7.1 per 1000 hospital births (interquartile range [IQR], 2.2-15.8), the 10-year unemployment rate was 7.6% (IQR, 6.4%-9.0%), and 83.9% of county-years were partial or complete mental health shortage areas. In the adjusted analyses, mental health shortage areas had higher NAS rates (unadjusted rate in shortage areas of 14.0 per 1000 births vs unadjusted rate in nonshortage areas of 10.6 per 1000 births; adjusted incidence rate ratio [IRR], 1.17 [95% CI, 1.07-1.27]), occurring primarily in metropolitan counties (adjusted IRR, 1.28 [95% CI, 1.16-1.40]; P = .02 for test of equivalence between metropolitan counties and rural counties adjacent to metropolitan counties). There was no significant association between primary care shortage areas and rates of NAS. The 10-year unemployment rate was associated with higher rates of NAS (unadjusted rate in highest unemployment quartile of 20.1 per 1000 births vs 7.8 per 1000 births in lowest unemployment quartile; adjusted IRR, 1.11 [95% CI, 1.00-1.23]) occurring primarily in rural remote counties (adjusted IRR, 1.34 [95% CI, 1.05-1.70]; P = .04 for test of equivalence between metropolitan counties and rural remote counties).

sec.title: Conclusions and Relevance
sec.p: In this ecological analysis of counties in 8 US states, there was a significant association among higher long-term unemployment, higher mental health clinician shortage areas, and higher county-level rates of neonatal abstinence syndrome.

abstract.p: This population epidemiology study assesses the association of US county-level long-term unemployment, primary care and mental health clinician supply, and urban vs rural status with rates of neonatal abstinence syndrome (NAS).

award-group.funding-source: National Institute for Healthcare Management Foundation
National Institute on Drug Abuse of the National Institutes of Health
